section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to review letters Rr, Ww, and Jj. introduce the book with a dance, and introduce the new vocabulary word (oceans).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking: What small things can you do to save water and trees?
Read for enjoyment and understanding.
Check for understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Relate own experiences to those in books.
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Identify rhyming words.
Take responsibility for shared materials and jobs.
Compare and contrast information from a text.
Use subject-verb agreement.
Show understanding and the importance of taking care of the planet.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe where light, heat, and electricity come from.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children produce the initial sounds for words beginning with Rr, Ww, and Jj.
Invite children to sort classroom objects with the target sounds.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we care for our world?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Are there any pictures of fish or an ocean in your book?
How would you show someone how to brush their teeth without wasting water?
What animals do you know that live in an ocean?
Can you draw and write about an animal that lives in the ocean?
Draw a picture of a big whale on one side of a paper. Turn it over and draw little fish on the other side.
What letter do you hear at the beginning of the word world? Can you find it and write it?
What could you build for owls to live in?

TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photo © Aleksey Sagitov/Shutterstock.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the take responsibility for materials and jobs Mind Builder and introduce vocabulary (take care, materials).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to The Earth Book.
Read closely and see how the children in the book take responsibility.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Relate own experiences to those in books.
Take responsibility for shared materials and jobs.
Use tools in new and different ways to work toward a goal.
Compare and contrast information from a text.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky.
Show understanding and the importance of taking care of the planet.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children to think about taking care of classroom materials.
Invite children to choose classroom materials and replace them to where they belong.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we care for our world?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Spend some of you time in the center cleaning it up and making sure things are in the right place.
Pretend you are the teacher. What would you tell the children to do to when they leave a room?
What things do you see here that are made out of plastic?
Can you make a sign to remind people in your family to close the refrigerator door?
Can you think of a present you could make using this empty clean shampoo bottle?
I’ll write the word rake. Can you write the words that rhyme with it—take, make, wake?
What is your classroom responsibility when you are done building?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build knowledge about how we use electricity, determine what things are made of, and introduce vocabulary (energy).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking: What can we do to save energy and recycle materials?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Relate own experiences to those in books.
Take responsibility for shared materials and jobs.
Use tools in new and different ways to work toward a goal.
Compare and contrast information from a text.
Use subject-verb agreement.
Show understanding and the importance of taking care of the planet.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe where light, heat, and electricity come from.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builder: Social Development; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to reuse paper and other materials to create art.
Encourage children to use their imaginations.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we care for our world?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Are there any pictures of things made out of plastic in your book?
Pretend you work in a recycling center. How would you sort the items?
What are some things from this center that we can recycle?
Can you make a note about recycling to bring home to your family?
Look at this paper towel roll. What could you make using it?
Read an Alphabet Book to a stuffed animal.
What can you build using plastic containers and lids?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Earth Book by Todd Parr. Copyright © 2010 by Todd Parr. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Little, Brown and Company, a division of Hachette Book Group, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photo © Aleksey Sagitov/Shutterstock.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: You Can Help

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Science: Physical Science; Earth and Space Science

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about helping care for the Earth and when to turn on or off lights, and introduce vocabulary (Earth, recycle).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts You Can Help and The Earth Book.
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question: How can we care for our world?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Relate own experiences to those in books.
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Write for different purposes; Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols; use top to bottom and left to right directionality when writing.
Compare and contrast information from a text.
Use subject-verb agreement.
Take responsibility for shared materials and jobs.
Show understanding and the importance of taking care of the planet.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe where light, heat, and electricity come from.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children to think about and then sort picture cards into three categories of activities to take care of the Earth.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we care for our world?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you share a book with a friend and find pictures of our wonderful Earth?
Can you show me how you could turn off the water while you soap up your hands to wash them?
Can you draw pictures of things that need electricity to make them work?
Can you create your own storybook page about taking care of the Earth?
Can you draw pictures of some animals who live on the Earth with us?
Can you write the letters Ww, Jj, and Rr? Can you use scraps to decorate them?
With a partner create a small recycling bin. Then create a second bin that is larger. Then one that is the largest.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Earth Book by Todd Parr. Copyright © 2010 by Todd Parr. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Little, Brown and Company, a division of Hachette Book Group, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Science: Physical Science; Earth and Space Science

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to engage children with a song about recycling, and introduce vocabulary (sparkle).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking: What are some little ways we can help the Earth?
Read and retell interactively for engagement and enjoyment.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share and repeat the details in a text.
Write for different purposes; Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols; use top to bottom and left to right directionality when writing.
Compare and contrast information from a text.
Take responsibility for shared materials and jobs.
Show understanding and the importance of taking care of the planet.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe where light, heat, and electricity come from.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s writing prompt: Why do you think it’s important to take care of Earth?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we care for our world?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you tell me about the characters in the story who help each other?
Imagine your house is built with recycled materials. What would your house look like?
How can you order these plastic containers from smallest to largest?
Can you write and draw about the stars that sparkle in the sky?
Can you create a collage with scraps of paper?
Can you read an Alphabet Book to a stuffed animal?
Imagine a building made of recycled materials. What would it look like? Build it.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Produce at least 20 distinct letter-sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Recognize rhyming words.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Take care of and manage classroom materials.
Demonstrate importance of caring for our environment and our planet.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Take care of and manage classroom materials.
Assume various roles and responsibilities as part of a classroom community.
Demonstrate importance of caring for our environment and our planet.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss sources of energy.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Take care of and manage classroom materials.
Assume various roles and responsibilities as part of a classroom community.
Use tools in new and different ways to work toward a goal.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss sources of energy, including light, heat, and electricity.
Demonstrate importance of caring for our environment and our planet.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Use appropriate directionality when writing.
Take care of and manage classroom materials.
Assume various roles and responsibilities as part of a classroom community.
Use tools in new and different ways to work toward a goal.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss sources of energy.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Use appropriate directionality when writing (top to bottom, left to right).
Take care of and manage classroom materials.
Demonstrate importance of caring for our environment and our planet.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
